thread.title: Struggling Serie A side Palermo make their ELEVENTH managerial change in just two seasons
thread.title_full: Struggling Serie A side Palermo make their ELEVENTH managerial change in just two seasons

author: Mark Jones
title: Struggling Serie A side Palermo make their ELEVENTH managerial change in just two seasons
text:
Sport Struggling Serie A side Palermo make their ELEVENTH managerial change in just two seasons The Rosanero aren't afraid of changing things around if things are going wrong, and Uruguayan Diego Lopez is the next man through the revolving door Share God speed, Diego. *salutes* (Photo: Claudio Villa) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Serie A side Palermo must be in possession of the hottest of hotseats. 
The Sicilian club - currently sitting second from bottom of the Italian top-flight - have just decided on a change of manager. You might think that there is nothing too strange in that given their predicament, until you realise that this is their ELEVENTH such change in two seasons! 
Club president Maurizio Zamparini is clearly not a man who likes to stand by his manager, and has made 60 changes over his 30 years as a club owners with various sides. Maurizio Zamparini: A man who likes to say "you're fired" more than Donald Trump 
Amazingly, he made EIGHT changes at Palermo last season alone. 
They started with Beppe Iachini, who was replaced by Davide Ballardini in November. In January, Ballardini got the chop and was replaced by Fabio Viviani - who had been working in the club’s analytics department - and who came in as caretaker. 
Viviani's first game saw Palermo thrashed 4-0 by Genoa… so he was instantly replaced by Giovanni Tedesco, who lasted three weeks and was replaced by Giovanni Bosi. Bosi took charge of one match, before Iachini was brought back to the club. Giuseppe Iachini, who must be a glutton for punishment as he came back (Photo: Tullio M. Puglia) Eugenio Corini is the latest to be sacked (Photo: Maurizio Lagana) 
Then in March, Iachini and Zamparini had a public bust-up which saw Iachini resign and Walter Novellino come in, and then out again. 
He was replaced by Ballardini again, who lasted until the start of this season, before he was replaced by Roberto De Zerbi in September. De Zerbi got the bullet in November to be replaced by Eugenio Corini, who has now been replaced by Lopez, formerly the boss at Cagliari and Bologna. Wouldn't it be easier just to sack the players? (Photo: Tullio M. Puglia) 
Got all that? 
Good luck Diego, you're going to need it. Like us on Facebook
